elements.content: Four new complexes with 2-((4-phenyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-1-yl)methyl)pyridine (ptmp) ligand: [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] (1), [PdCl3(Hptmp)]·H2O (2), (Hptmp)2[AuCl4]Cl (3), and [Hg4Br8(ptmp)2] n (4) were prepared and their crystal structures were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. Three nitrogen atoms of the ligand ptmp are prone to coordinate to the metal ions. In complex 1 ligand ptmp coordinates monodentately through the pyridyl N4 atom to the axial site of Rh. In compound 2 the N4 protonated ptmp, Hptmp +, coordinates Pd by the triazole N3 nitrogen atom. Ionic compound 3 is composed of three types of ions, Hptmp +, AuCl4 −, and Cl−, interconnected by hydrogen bonds. Mercury complex 4 is a coordination polymer in which two ptmp ligands stabilize the Hg4Br8 chain, and the coordination involves N2 and N3 nitrogen atoms of the triazole and the pyridyl nitrogen atom N4. The crystal structures of 1−4 are dominated by hydrogen-bonding, C−H···π, and π−π stacking interactions. The potential of ptmp to enable supramolecular associations is examined.

elements.content: Ligand 2-((4-phenyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-1-yl)methyl)pyridine (ptmp) is able to coordinate to the metal centers with three different heterocyclic nitrogen atoms in mono- or multidentate mode. In the crystal structure, ptmp enables distinct supramolecular associations through hydrogen-bonding, C−H···π, and π−π stacking interactions, as exemplified by the complexes with Rh(II), Pd(II), Au(III), and Hg(II) ions.

elements.content: Hybrid inorganic−organic compounds are of considerable interest because of their extensive structural diversity and their potential applications in nonlinear optics, electrical conductivity, catalysis, ion-exchange, biochemistry, etc. The tendencies of the hybrids to form supramolecular structures arise from both the strong and especially weak interactions. The latter can alter the predicted structures in a dramatic way. The structures and thus the properties of these materials can be readily modified by changing the metal ion and/or the ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Hybrid inorganic-organic compounds are of considerable interest because of their extensive structural diversity and their potential applications in nonlinear optics, electrical conductivity, catalysis, ion-exchange, biochemistry, etc. The tendencies of the hybrids to form supramolecular structures arise from both the strong and especially weak interactions. The latter can alter the predicted structures in a dramatic way. The structures and thus the properties of these materials can be readily modified by changing the metal ion and/or the ligand.

elements.content: 1,4-Disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles, prepared through copper(I)-catalyzed 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition of alkynes to azides, which belongs to a group of reactions referred to as “click chemistry”, are emerging as powerful “click chelators” receiving considerable attention from a number of different research groups worldwide. Recently, 2-((4-phenyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-1-yl)methyl)pyridine (ptmp, Chart ) has been explored as “click chelator” for Cu(II), Ag(I), Co(II), Ni(II), and Zn(I). We have experimentally and theoretically addressed the chelaton of ptmp to Cu(II), Ru(II), Pd(II), Ag(I), and Pt(II). On the basis of X-ray structural analyses, in all the above examples the chelation involved the triazole N2 and pyridyl N4 nitrogen atoms to form six-membered metallacycles with various geometries around the metal centers. In addition to the parent ptmp ligand, the crystal structures that contain the similar ptmp binding moiety have also been reported.

elements.content: The potential of this ligand to form interesting supramolecular arrays and novel coordination modes is now evaluated with other metal ions. The synthesis and X-ray characterization of four structures with ptmp scaffold: [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] (1), [PdCl3(Hptmp)]·H2O (2), [Hptmp]2[AuCl4]Cl (3) and [Hg4Br8(ptmp)2] n (4) is described. In these compounds, the ptmp molecule serves as an efficient mono- or multidentate coordinating ligand with three potential nitrogen-containing coordination sites and three (hetero)aromatic rings offering several possibilities for noncovalent interactions. These include hydrogen bonding, π−π stacking interactions, and C−H···π interactions.

elements.content: Reagents and solvents were used as purchased from Fluka and Aldrich. Ligand ptmp was prepared as previously reported. NMR spectra were recorded at 302 K on a Bruker Avance DPX 300 spectrometer operating at 300 MHz (1H) and 75 MHz (13C). Proton and carbon spectra were referenced to TMS as an internal standard at δ = 0 ppm. Chemical shifts are given on the δ scale (ppm), and coupling constants (J) are given in Hertz. Mass spectra and high-resolution mass spectra were obtained with a Q-TOF Premier instrument. Data are reported as m/z (relative intensity). Infrared spectra were recorded on a BIO-RAD Excalibur Series spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O analyzer. Melting points were determined on a Kofler block.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General

Reagents and solvents were used as purchased from Fluka and Aldrich. Ligand ptmp was prepared as previously reported. NMR spectra were recorded at 302 K on a Bruker Avance DPX 300 spectrometer operating at 300 MHz (1H) and 75 MHz (13C). Proton and carbon spectra were referenced to TMS as an internal standard at δ = 0 ppm. Chemical shifts are given on the δ scale (ppm), and coupling constants (J) are given in Hertz. Mass spectra and high-resolution mass spectra were obtained with a Q-TOF Premier instrument. Data are reported as m/z (relative intensity). Infrared spectra were recorded on a BIO-RAD Excalibur Series spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O analyzer. Melting points were determined on a Kofler block.

elements.content: [Rh2(O2CCH3)4] (103 mg, 0.23 mmol) was dissolved in a boiling mixture of water (20 mL) and MeOH (5 mL), and filtered. The filtrate was reheated to the boiling point, and a solution of ptmp (108 mg, 0.46 mmol) in MeOH (5 mL) was slowly added at stirring. Purple precipitate formed immediately. The reaction mixture was stirred for a few minutes and then it was left to cool to room temperature. The precipitate was collected by filtration and washed sequentially with water (3 × 5 mL), MeOH (2 × 5 mL), and Et2O (2 × 5 mL) to give [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)] (130 mg, 86%). Mp > 250 °C. Anal. Calcd for C22H24N4O8Rh2·H2O: C, 37.95; H, 3.76; N, 8.05. Found: C, 38.35; H, 3.47; N, 8.10. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMF-d 7) δ 1.80 (s, 12H), 6.21 (br s, 2H), 7.30−7.40 (m, 2H), 7.40−7.55 (m, 2H), 7.60−7.70 (m, 1H), 7.90−8.10 (m, 3H), 8.76 (s, 1H), 8.86 (br s, 1H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, DMF-d 7) δ 23.1, 122.9, 123.2, 124.4, 126.0, 128.6, 129.6, 131.9, 148.0, 190.6. IR (KBr) ν 3412, 1589, 1347, 1416, 699 cm−1. HRMS (ESI+) Calcd for C22H25N4O8 103Rh2 [M + H]+: 678.9782. Found: 678.9800.

elements.content: Complex [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)] was dissolved in a minimum amount of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) by gentle heating. The resulting solution was aged at room temperature in an open vial for five days to give two different types of crystals, which were separated by hand. The single crystal X-ray analyses revealed the formation of [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] (1) and [Rh2(DMSO)2(O2CCH3)4].

elements.content: Crystal data and refinement parameters of compounds 1−4 are listed in Table . The X-ray intensity data were collected at room temperature with a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were processed by using DENZO. The structures were solved by direct methods (SIR-92) and refined by a full-matrix least-squares procedure based on F 2 using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were included in the model at geometrically calculated positions and refined using a riding model. The N-bound hydrogen atoms were located in a difference map and refined with the using distance restraints (DFIX) with N−H = 0.86 and with U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(N). The water hydrogen atoms in 2 were not located. The residual density peak in 4 (2.006 Å from Hg1) was unrefineable and therefore was not included in the model.

Crystallography

Crystal data and refinement parameters of compounds 1-4 are listed in Table . The X-ray intensity data were collected at room temperature with a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were processed by using DENZO. The structures were solved by direct methods (SIR-92) and refined by a full-matrix least-squares procedure based on F 2 using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were included in the model at geometrically calculated positions and refined using a riding model. The N-bound hydrogen atoms were located in a difference map and refined with the using distance restraints (DFIX) with N-H = 0.86 and with U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(N). The water hydrogen atoms in 2 were not located. The residual density peak in 4 (2.006 Å from Hg1) was unrefineable and therefore was not included in the model.

Dirhodium(II) tetracarboxylates easily form complexes [Rh2(O2CR)4L n ] (n = 1 or 2) with different ligands (L) in the axial positions. In our case, the addition of ptmp into a hot MeOH/water solution of rhodium(II) acetate dimer [Rh2(O2CCH3)4] resulted in an instant precipitation of a purple solid. On the basis of the analytical and spectroscopic data, its structure was elucidated as a one-ligand-one-rhodium(II) acetate dimer compound, [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)]. The coordination of the ptmp ligand to Rh through the pyridyl nitrogen atom N4 was suggested by the 1H NMR spectra in which the resonance of the proton ortho to the coordinating nitrogen atom of the pyridine ring (8.86 ppm) and the protons of the methylene group (6.21 ppm) were broadened. This broadening can be explained by a rotational motion of ptmp ligand around the Rh−N4 axis. The dynamics is slow on the NMR time scale, which can be accounted for by steric repulsion between the ligand and the acetate oxygen atoms of the dinuclear [Rh2(O2CCH3)4] paddle-wheel unit. The broadening of the protons of the methylene group can additionally be attributed to a hampered rotational motion of the pyridyl and triazole rings along the C−C and C−N single bonds with the methylene group. The crystallization of [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)] from DMSO afforded two different types of crystals [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] (1) and [Rh2(DMSO)2(O2CCH3)4].

Synthesis of [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] (1)

Dirhodium(II) tetracarboxylates easily form complexes [Rh2(O2CR)4L n ] (n = 1 or 2) with different ligands (L) in the axial positions. In our case, the addition of ptmp into a hot MeOH/water solution of rhodium(II) acetate dimer [Rh2(O2CCH3)4] resulted in an instant precipitation of a purple solid. On the basis of the analytical and spectroscopic data, its structure was elucidated as a one-ligand-one-rhodium(II) acetate dimer compound, [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)]. The coordination of the ptmp ligand to Rh through the pyridyl nitrogen atom N4 was suggested by the 1H NMR spectra in which the resonance of the proton ortho to the coordinating nitrogen atom of the pyridine ring (8.86 ppm) and the protons of the methylene group (6.21 ppm) were broadened. This broadening can be explained by a rotational motion of ptmp ligand around the Rh-N4 axis. The dynamics is slow on the NMR time scale, which can be accounted for by steric repulsion between the ligand and the acetate oxygen atoms of the dinuclear [Rh2(O2CCH3)4] paddle-wheel unit. The broadening of the protons of the methylene group can additionally be attributed to a hampered rotational motion of the pyridyl and triazole rings along the C-C and C-N single bonds with the methylene group. The crystallization of [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)] from DMSO afforded two different types of crystals [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] (1) and [Rh2(DMSO)2(O2CCH3)4].

elements.content: The preparation of 2 was achieved in two steps. First, the reaction of PdCl2 with ptmp afforded [PdCl2(ptmp)] in which the ligand is bidentately coordinated to Pd through the pyridyl N4 nitrogen atom and N2 nitrogen atom of the triazole ring. The structure of [PdCl2(ptmp)] was suggested on the basis of combustion analysis results and the 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectroscopic analogy with the previously reported analogous platinum(II) complex, [PtCl2(ptmp)]. In the second step, crystallization of [PdCl2(ptmp)] from HCl afforded [PdCl3(Hptmp)]·H2O (2).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [PdCl3(Hptmp)]⋅H2O (2)

The preparation of 2 was achieved in two steps. First, the reaction of PdCl2 with ptmp afforded [PdCl2(ptmp)] in which the ligand is bidentately coordinated to Pd through the pyridyl N4 nitrogen atom and N2 nitrogen atom of the triazole ring. The structure of [PdCl2(ptmp)] was suggested on the basis of combustion analysis results and the 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectroscopic analogy with the previously reported analogous platinum(II) complex, [PtCl2(ptmp)]. In the second step, crystallization of [PdCl2(ptmp)] from HCl afforded [PdCl3(Hptmp)]⋅H2O (2).

elements.content: The syntheses of compounds 3 and 4 were achieved by simple mixing of ligand ptmp with AuCl3 and HgBr2, respectively, in MeOH as a solvent. The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra of 4 are identical to those of ptmp, indicating fast ligand exchange reaction in the solution. The 1H NMR spectrum of 3 closely resembles that of Hptmp +. Unfortunately, no satisfactorily elemental analysis for compound 3 could be obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of (Hptmp)2[AuCl4]Cl (3) and [Hg4Br8(ptmp)2] n  (4)

The syntheses of compounds 3 and 4 were achieved by simple mixing of ligand ptmp with AuCl3 and HgBr2, respectively, in MeOH as a solvent. The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra of 4 are identical to those of ptmp, indicating fast ligand exchange reaction in the solution. The 1H NMR spectrum of 3 closely resembles that of Hptmp +. Unfortunately, no satisfactorily elemental analysis for compound 3 could be obtained.

elements.content: The crystal structure of compound 1 consists of isolated dinuclear complexes of [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] in which two rhodium(II) centers are bridged by four carboxylato ligands. The axial positions are occupied with ptmp ligands through the coordination of the pyridyl N4 atom (Figure ). The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of half of the complex [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] with the center of symmetry in the midpoint of the Rh−Rh single bond. The Rh−Rh distance is 2.402 Å, which is typical for [Rh2(μ-carboxylate)4] complexes. The axial Rh−N4 distance of 2.290 Å is between the longest (i.e., 2.227(39) Å in [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(py)2]) and the shortest Rh−Nax bond distances (i.e., 2.407(1) Å in [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(tpy)2]; tpy = 2,2′:6′,2′′-terpyridine).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] (1)

The crystal structure of compound 1 consists of isolated dinuclear complexes of [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] in which two rhodium(II) centers are bridged by four carboxylato ligands. The axial positions are occupied with ptmp ligands through the coordination of the pyridyl N4 atom (Figure ). The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of half of the complex [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] with the center of symmetry in the midpoint of the Rh-Rh single bond. The Rh-Rh distance is 2.402 Å, which is typical for [Rh2(μ-carboxylate)4] complexes. The axial Rh-N4 distance of 2.290 Å is between the longest (i.e., 2.227(39) Å in [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(py)2]) and the shortest Rh-Nax bond distances (i.e., 2.407(1) Å in [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(tpy)2]; tpy = 2,2':6',2''-terpyridine).

elements.content: In the crystal lattice of 1 short C3−H3···N2 and C4−H4···N3 interactions form hydrogen−bonded 2D layers perpendicular to the b-axis. These are assisted by π−π interactions between the pyridyl and the triazole rings (Figure a). These layers are further interconnected via another hydrogen-bonding motif through C5b−H5b···N3 interactions (Figure b), thus completing the 3D architecture.
elements.clean_text: In the crystal lattice of 1 short C3-H3⋅⋅⋅N2 and C4-H4⋅⋅⋅N3 interactions form hydrogen-bonded 2D layers perpendicular to the b-axis. These are assisted by π-π interactions between the pyridyl and the triazole rings (Figure a). These layers are further interconnected via another hydrogen-bonding motif through C5b-H5b⋅⋅⋅N3 interactions (Figure b), thus completing the 3D architecture.

elements.content: In the crystal structure of 1, there are also intermolecular C−H···π interactions, as shown in Figure . The hydrogen atoms H1b and H5b are in close proximity to the centers of the phenyl and triazole rings, respectively. The distances of H1b and H5b from the centroids of the phenyl ring and the triazole ring are 2.928 and 2.825 Å, whereas the C1−H1b···π (centroid of the phenyl) and the C5b−H5b···π (centroid of the triazole) angles are 160.2° and 154.2°, respectively. Along with these C−H···π interactions, an additional pair of π−π interactions between the triazole and phenyl rings completes the 2D network of the ptmp ligand.
elements.clean_text: In the crystal structure of 1, there are also intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions, as shown in Figure . The hydrogen atoms H1b and H5b are in close proximity to the centers of the phenyl and triazole rings, respectively. The distances of H1b and H5b from the centroids of the phenyl ring and the triazole ring are 2.928 and 2.825 Å, whereas the C1-H1b⋅⋅⋅π (centroid of the phenyl) and the C5b-H5b⋅⋅⋅π (centroid of the triazole) angles are 160.2° and 154.2°, respectively. Along with these C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions, an additional pair of π-π interactions between the triazole and phenyl rings completes the 2D network of the ptmp ligand.

elements.content: The Pd(II) center is tetra-coordinated in a square-planar environment (Figure ). The Hptmp + ligand is monodentately coordinated through the triazole N3 atom with a Pd−N3 bond distance of 2.008 Å. This is comparable to the previously reported bond separation of 2.007 Å between the 1,2,3-triazole N3 nitrogen atom coordinated to Pd(II). The Pd−Cl bond distances in complex 2 are in the range of 2.300−2.291 Å, similar to the literature reports for the PdCl3N coordination environment. The sum of the Pd containing angles equals 360°. Slight narrowing of the N3−Pd−Cl and widening of the Cl−Pd−Cl angles from the ideal 90° is observed in 2, which is typical for [PdCl3L] complexes. The angle between the triazole ring and the metal coordination plane is 84.19°.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [PdCl3(Hptmp)]⋅H2O (2)

The Pd(II) center is tetra-coordinated in a square-planar environment (Figure ). The Hptmp + ligand is monodentately coordinated through the triazole N3 atom with a Pd-N3 bond distance of 2.008 Å. This is comparable to the previously reported bond separation of 2.007 Å between the 1,2,3-triazole N3 nitrogen atom coordinated to Pd(II). The Pd-Cl bond distances in complex 2 are in the range of 2.300-2.291 Å, similar to the literature reports for the PdCl3N coordination environment. The sum of the Pd containing angles equals 360°. Slight narrowing of the N3-Pd-Cl and widening of the Cl-Pd-Cl angles from the ideal 90° is observed in 2, which is typical for [PdCl3L] complexes. The angle between the triazole ring and the metal coordination plane is 84.19°.

elements.content: In compound 2 there are several hydrogen-bonding interactions, including C−H···O, C−H···Cl, O−H···Cl, and N−H···Cl. The weak intermolecular contacts between several C−H groups of the ptmp ligand and the Pd-coordinated chlorine atoms, as well as the oxygen atoms of the uncoordinated lattice water molecules, form a 2D sheet arrangement, perpendicular to the b-axis (Figure a). The lattice water molecules act as hydrogen-bond acceptors from two C−H groups (C1 and C3b) and are simultaneously hydrogen-bond donors toward Cl3 and Cl1 atoms, as illustrated in Figure , panels a and b, respectively. Although the diffraction pattern did not allow fixing of the hydrogen atoms of the lattice water molecules, the distances between O1 and Cl1 (Cl3) of 3.206 Å (3.262 Å) unambiguously confirm the hydrogen-bonding interactions. The planes of the pyridyl and phenyl rings alternately stack in the direction of a-axis. The distances between the centroids of these two rings (4.144 Å and 4.452 Å, respectively) are too long for a typical π−π stacking, but the position of the ring planes, being in a face-to-face and slipped-type parallel alignment, still suggest the presence of some weak interactions. Finally, the protonated pyridyl N4 nitrogen atom is a hydrogen-bond donor to the Cl2 atom, which, along with the above-mentioned O1···Cl1 interaction, sticks 2D layers together into a 3D supramolecular architecture (Figure b).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 3 consists of two half of two Au(III) atoms, four coordinated chloride ions (two per every half gold atom), one noncoordinated chloride ion, and two Hptmp + cations. Figure a shows the packing of the structural units. Both gold atoms are placed on a center of inversion to form two [AuCl4]− units in the crystal structure. The coordination environment of the gold atom is square planar with the Au−Cl distances from 2.272 Å to 2.279 Å, which is typical for the [AuCl4]− ions. The structure of 3 is interesting from the fact that Hptmp + does not form any coordination bond to the Au atoms, either by N2 or N3 coordination sites of the triazole ring.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of (Hptmp)2[AuCl4]Cl (3) 

The asymmetric unit of 3 consists of two half of two Au(III) atoms, four coordinated chloride ions (two per every half gold atom), one noncoordinated chloride ion, and two Hptmp + cations. Figure a shows the packing of the structural units. Both gold atoms are placed on a center of inversion to form two [AuCl4]- units in the crystal structure. The coordination environment of the gold atom is square planar with the Au-Cl distances from 2.272 Å to 2.279 Å, which is typical for the [AuCl4]- ions. The structure of 3 is interesting from the fact that Hptmp + does not form any coordination bond to the Au atoms, either by N2 or N3 coordination sites of the triazole ring.

elements.content: In compound 3, the isolated Cl− ion is an acceptor of three hydrogen bonds from two pyridyl N4 atoms and one methylene C−H···Cl interaction. The [AuCl4]− anions and Hptmp + cations are linked by four C−H···Cl hydrogen bonds. The weak hydrogen bonds, assisted with π−π interactions between the pyridyl, phenyl, and triazole rings form 2D layers perpendicular to the b-axes (Figure a). These layers are packed into a 3D supramolecular architecture by the assistance of two noncovalent interactions: π−π interaction between the phenyl and the pyridyl rings (4.082 Å) and Au2−Cl3···π (pyridyl) interactions (3.496 Å) of the second [AuCl4]− ion in the crystal structure (Figure b).

The weak hydrogen bonds, assisted with π-π interactions between the pyridyl, phenyl, and triazole rings form 2D layers perpendicular to the b-axes (Figure a). These layers are packed into a 3D supramolecular architecture by the assistance of two noncovalent interactions: π-π interaction between the phenyl and the pyridyl rings (4.082 Å) and Au2-Cl3⋅⋅⋅π (pyridyl) interactions (3.496 Å) of the second [AuCl4]- ion in the crystal structure (Figure b).

elements.content: The structure of 4 features a linear homonuclear Hg(II) bromide oligomer in which the monomeric Hg4Br8 chain is bridged by two ptmp ligands (Figure ). All bromine atoms in this chain are in the bridging position. The Hg−N distances are in the range from 2.500 Å to 2.708 Å. The Hg−Br distances are of two types. First, there are the Hg−Br bond distances of ca. 2.4 Å, comparable to those in the discrete HgBr2 molecules. Second, there are the Hg−Br distances ranging from 3.235 Å to 3.487 Å suggesting weak Hg···Br interactions. All Hg atoms in the chain are almost collinear, with the angles between the neighboring Hg atoms of 149.591° and 175.320°. The coordination geometry around the two neighboring Hg2 ions in this chain can be described as slightly distorted square pyramid that is composed of four Br atoms in the basal position and one triazole N3 atom of ptmp in the apical position (Figure ). On the other hand, the coordination polyhedron around the neighboring two Hg1 ions in the chain is a distorted octahedron composed of two ptmp nitrogen atoms, N2 and N4, and four Br atoms. The whole structure is stabilized by the C3−H3···Br3 hydrogen bonding interaction and π−π stacking between two pyridyl rings (3.625 Å) and between the triazole and phenyl rings (3.864 Å), constructing 2D layers of inorganic and organic species (Figure a). These layers are arranged into a supramolecular 3D array with additional C5b−H5b···Br3 hydrogen bonds and π−π interactions between the centers of the triazole and pyridyl rings, separated by 3.848 Å.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Hg4Br8(ptmp)2] n  (4)

The structure of 4 features a linear homonuclear Hg(II) bromide oligomer in which the monomeric Hg4Br8 chain is bridged by two ptmp ligands (Figure ). All bromine atoms in this chain are in the bridging position. The Hg-N distances are in the range from 2.500 Å to 2.708 Å. The Hg-Br distances are of two types. First, there are the Hg-Br bond distances of ca. 2.4 Å, comparable to those in the discrete HgBr2 molecules. Second, there are the Hg-Br distances ranging from 3.235 Å to 3.487 Å suggesting weak Hg⋅⋅⋅Br interactions. All Hg atoms in the chain are almost collinear, with the angles between the neighboring Hg atoms of 149.591° and 175.320°. The coordination geometry around the two neighboring Hg2 ions in this chain can be described as slightly distorted square pyramid that is composed of four Br atoms in the basal position and one triazole N3 atom of ptmp in the apical position (Figure ). On the other hand, the coordination polyhedron around the neighboring two Hg1 ions in the chain is a distorted octahedron composed of two ptmp nitrogen atoms, N2 and N4, and four Br atoms. The whole structure is stabilized by the C3-H3⋅⋅⋅Br3 hydrogen bonding interaction and π-π stacking between two pyridyl rings (3.625 Å) and between the triazole and phenyl rings (3.864 Å), constructing 2D layers of inorganic and organic species (Figure a). These layers are arranged into a supramolecular 3D array with additional C5b-H5b⋅⋅⋅Br3 hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions between the centers of the triazole and pyridyl rings, separated by 3.848 Å.

elements.content: In principle, the ptmp ligand can coordinate to the metal center with three different nitrogen atoms, N2 and N3 of the triazole unit and N4 of the pyridine ring, and is potentially chelating. It should be noted that these nitrogen atoms possess remarkably different electron densities. As supported by DFT calculations for ptmp, the natural bonding orbital (NBO) charges follow the order N2 (−0.07) > N3 (−0.27) > N4 (−0.48), with the pyridyl N4 atom being a significantly more electron-rich donor. However, the dependence of the stability of the complexes upon the basicity of the heterocyclic N-donor ligands should be taken with care because π-back-donation from the filled orbitals of the metal to the antibonding orbitals of the ligand may play an important role.
elements.clean_text:
Survey of the ptmp Coordination Modes in the Complexes under Investigation

In principle, the ptmp ligand can coordinate to the metal center with three different nitrogen atoms, N2 and N3 of the triazole unit and N4 of the pyridine ring, and is potentially chelating. It should be noted that these nitrogen atoms possess remarkably different electron densities. As supported by DFT calculations for ptmp, the natural bonding orbital (NBO) charges follow the order N2 (-0.07) > N3 (-0.27) > N4 (-0.48), with the pyridyl N4 atom being a significantly more electron-rich donor. However, the dependence of the stability of the complexes upon the basicity of the heterocyclic N-donor ligands should be taken with care because π-back-donation from the filled orbitals of the metal to the antibonding orbitals of the ligand may play an important role.

elements.content: The coordination of the ptmp ligand to the dirhodium core by the pyridyl N4 atom into the complex 1 can be rationalized by considering the above NBO charges and the relatively mild reaction conditions employed for its synthesis (). It is well established that whereas dirhodium(II) tetracarboxylates [Rh2(O2CR)4] readily form adducts in which the axial sites are occupied by the ligands, the substitution of the bridging carboxylates by the N−N chelating ligands often requires more forcing reaction conditions such as prolonged heating. At this point of research, we did not investigate further if ptmp is also capable of such coordination.

At this point of research, we did not investigate further if ptmp is also capable of such coordination.

elements.content: In the case of palladium, under neutral conditions the ptmp ligand bidentately coordinates PdCl2 through N2 and N4 atoms into [PdCl2(ptmp)] (vide supra), which is consistent with the previously reported platinum and palladium complexes, [PtCl2(ptmp)] and [Pd(ptmp)2](BF4)2, respectively. Under heating in aqueous HCl, this complex undergoes structural changes into [PdCl3(Hptmp)]·H2O (2), in which the most basic nitrogen atom N4 is protonated and the second most electron-rich nitrogen atom (N3) coordinates palladium. Examples in which the click triazole is via N3 atom monodentately coordinated to palladium(II) are precedented.
elements.clean_text: In the case of palladium, under neutral conditions the ptmp ligand bidentately coordinates PdCl2 through N2 and N4 atoms into [PdCl2(ptmp)] (vide supra), which is consistent with the previously reported platinum and palladium complexes, [PtCl2(ptmp)] and [Pd(ptmp)2](BF4)2, respectively. Under heating in aqueous HCl, this complex undergoes structural changes into [PdCl3(Hptmp)]⋅H2O (2), in which the most basic nitrogen atom N4 is protonated and the second most electron-rich nitrogen atom (N3) coordinates palladium. Examples in which the click triazole is via N3 atom monodentately coordinated to palladium(II) are precedented.

elements.content: Under the acidic conditions (AuCl3 in MeOH) employed for the synthesis of the gold(III) compound, the protonation of the ptmp pyridyl nitrogen atom and the formation of tetrachloroaurate(III) salt (Hptmp)2[AuCl4]Cl (3) is not entirely unexpected. Similar observations were made for other pyridine containing ligands in the presence of H[AuCl4]; however, examples are also known in which the latter readily forms pyridyl complexes under acidic conditions at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: Under the acidic conditions (AuCl3 in MeOH) employed for the synthesis of the gold(III) compound, the protonation of the ptmp pyridyl nitrogen atom and the formation of tetrachloroaurate(III) salt (Hptmp)2[AuCl4]Cl (3) is not entirely unexpected. Similar observations were made for other pyridine containing ligands in the presence of H[AuCl4]; however, examples are also known in which the latter readily forms pyridyl complexes under acidic conditions at room temperature.

elements.content: Since the synthesis of the mercury complex was carried out under neutral reaction conditions, the involvement of any of the three nitrogen donors (N2, N3, N4) at ptmp could potentially be expected to participate in the coordination. Indeed, this was the case in [Hg4Br8(ptmp)2] n (4). Providing the appropriate organic ligands, the formation of Hg2X2 bridges and infinite metal chains is frequently found in the structural chemistry of mercury halides. Although click triazole containing molecules have been designed as sensors and receptors for Hg(II) ions, to our knowledge, no crystallographically characterized complexes have been reported to date.

elements.content: The syntheses and crystal structures of four new Rh(II), Pd(II), Au(III), and Hg(II) complexes with 2-((4-phenyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-1-yl)methyl)pyridine (ptmp) are described. The ptmp ligand can exhibit a variety of bonding modes to the metal ions. For instance, it is able to coordinate through the pyridyl N4 atom in the axial positions of dirhodium(II) carboxylate to form complex [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] (1). On the other hand, the coordination of N4 protonated Hptmp + ligand to the palladium(II) involves triazole N3 atom, resulting in [PdCl3(Hptmp)]·H2O (2). By simple dissolving of HgBr2 and ptmp in MeOH at room temperature, the metallosupramolecular structure with the formula of [Hg4Br8(ptmp)2] n (4) is spontaneously assembled in which ptmp acts as a tridentate ligand. In contrast to 1, 2, and 4 such a coordination with ptmp was not observed in gold compound (Hptmp)2[AuCl4]Cl (3). Instead, in this case an ionic type compound was isolated where cations of Hptmp + compensate the charge of [AuCl4]− and chloride anions. Ligand ptmp is not only able to coordinate to the metal centers with three different heterocyclic nitrogen atoms in mono- or multidentate mode, but it also assists the stabilization of 2D and 3D supramolecular networks by distinct hydrogen-bonding, C−H···π and π−π stacking interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The syntheses and crystal structures of four new Rh(II), Pd(II), Au(III), and Hg(II) complexes with 2-((4-phenyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-1-yl)methyl)pyridine (ptmp) are described. The ptmp ligand can exhibit a variety of bonding modes to the metal ions. For instance, it is able to coordinate through the pyridyl N4 atom in the axial positions of dirhodium(II) carboxylate to form complex [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)2] (1). On the other hand, the coordination of N4 protonated Hptmp + ligand to the palladium(II) involves triazole N3 atom, resulting in [PdCl3(Hptmp)]⋅H2O (2). By simple dissolving of HgBr2 and ptmp in MeOH at room temperature, the metallosupramolecular structure with the formula of [Hg4Br8(ptmp)2] n  (4) is spontaneously assembled in which ptmp acts as a tridentate ligand. In contrast to 1, 2, and 4 such a coordination with ptmp was not observed in gold compound (Hptmp)2[AuCl4]Cl (3). Instead, in this case an ionic type compound was isolated where cations of Hptmp + compensate the charge of [AuCl4]- and chloride anions. Ligand ptmp is not only able to coordinate to the metal centers with three different heterocyclic nitrogen atoms in mono- or multidentate mode, but it also assists the stabilization of 2D and 3D supramolecular networks by distinct hydrogen-bonding, C-H⋅⋅⋅π and π-π stacking interactions.

[Rh2(O2CCH3)4] (103 mg, 0.23 mmol) was dissolved in a boiling mixture of water (20 mL) and MeOH (5 mL), and filtered. The filtrate was reheated to the boiling point, and a solution of ptmp (108 mg, 0.46 mmol) in MeOH (5 mL) was slowly added at stirring. Purple precipitate formed immediately. The reaction mixture was stirred for a few minutes and then it was left to cool to room temperature. The precipitate was collected by filtration and washed sequentially with water (3 × 5 mL), MeOH (2 × 5 mL), and Et2O (2 × 5 mL) to give [Rh2(O2CCH3)4(ptmp)] (130 mg, 86%). Mp > 250 °C. Anal. Calcd for C22H24N4O8Rh2·H2O: C, 37.95; H, 3.76; N, 8.05. Found: C, 38.35; H, 3.47; N, 8.10. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMF-d 7) δ 1.80 (s, 12H), 6.21 (br s, 2H), 7.30−7.40 (m, 2H), 7.40−7.55 (m, 2H), 7.60−7.70 (m, 1H), 7.90−8.10 (m, 3H), 8.76 (s, 1H), 8.86 (br s, 1H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, DMF-d 7) δ 23.1, 122.9, 123.2, 124.4, 126.0, 128.6, 129.6, 131.9, 148.0, 190.6. IR (KBr) ν 3412, 1589, 1347, 1416, 699 cm−1. HRMS (ESI+) Calcd for C22H25N4O8 103Rh2 [M + H]+: 678.9782. Found: 678.9800.

Synthesis of [PdCl<sub>3</sub>(Hptmp)]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

PdCl2 (47.5 mmol, 0.268 mmol) was dissolved in hot HCl (1 M, 3 mL). The resulting solution was allowed to cool down to room temperature, and a solution of ptmp (63.3 mmol, 0.268 mmol) in MeOH (1 mL) was added slowly at stirring. Yellow solid started to precipitate instantly. The stirring was continued for 15 min. The precipitate was collected by filtration, washed sequentially with water (3 × 2 mL), MeOH (3 mL) and Et2O (2 × 3 mL), and dried to give [PdCl2(ptmp)] (102 mg, 92%). Mp > 250 °C. Anal. Calcd for C14H12Cl2N4Pd: C, 40.66; H, 2.92; N, 13.55. Found: C, 40.68; H, 3.08; N, 13.44. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMF-d 7) δ 6.55 (s, 2H), 7.42−7.55 (m, 3H), 7.72−7.77 (m, 1H), 7.89−7.92 (m, 2H), 7.99−8.09 (m, 1H), 8.26 (ddd, J = 1.5, 7.5, 7.5 Hz, 1H), 9.11 (dd, J = 0.6, 5.7 Hz, 1H), 9.14 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, DMF-d 7) δ 55.2, 126.3, 126.5, 126.8, 127.2, 129.7, 129.8, 141.8, 149.3, 151.9, 154.7. IR (KBr) ν 3102, 3082, 3028, 1630, 1609, 1477, 1434, 766, 723, 692 cm−1.

Synthesis of (Hptmp)<sub>2</sub>[AuCl<sub>4</sub>]Cl (<bold>3</bold>)

Ligand ptmp (109 mg, 0.46 mmol) was added to a solution of AuCl3 (139 mg, 0.46 mmol) in MeOH (3 mL). After being stirred for 2 h at room temperature, the solvent was evaporated on a rotary evaporator and the residue was redissolved in acetone (3 mL). The resulting solution was left in quiet at room temperature for a few days, allowing half of the acetone to evaporate. Yellow crystals of 3 (115 mg, 60% based on ptmp), suitable for X-ray analysis, were collected by filtration and washed with a few drops of acetone. Mp 140−145 °C. Calcd for C28H26AuCl5N8: C, 39.62; H, 3.09; N, 13.20. Found: C, 37.83; H, 2.99; N, 12.58. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3OD) δ 5.90 (s, 2H), 7.25−7.33 (m, 1H), 7.34−7.43 (m, 2H), 7.64 (br d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.71 (br dd, J = 6.3, 6.3 Hz, 1H), 7.75−7.82 (m, 2H), 8.22 (dd, J = 7.8, 7.8 Hz, 1H), 8.41 (s, 1H), 8.70 (br s, 1H). IR (KBr) ν 2531, 1618, 1468, 760, 694 cm−1.

Synthesis of [Hg<sub>4</sub>Br<sub>8</sub>(<bold>ptmp</bold>)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture of ptmp (12 mg, 0.05 mmol) and HgBr2 (36 mmol, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in MeOH (1 mL) by gentle heating for a few minutes. The mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature. White crystals of [Hg4Br8(ptmp)2] n (4, 39 mg, 82%) that formed overnight were collected. Mp 168−172 °C. IR (KBr) ν 1614, 1477, 1466, 1439, 1230, 1194, 1080, 1053, 1005, 815, 757, 723, 687 cm−1. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMF-d 7) δ 5.88 (s, 2H), 7.31−7.43 (m, 3H), 7.43−7.50 (m, 2H), 7.87 (ddd, J = 1.8, 7.7, 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.92−7.98 (m, 2H), 8.62 (br d, J = 4.2 Hz, 1H), 8.71 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, DMF-d 7) δ 55.5, 122.7, 123.1, 124.0, 126.0, 128.5, 129.5, 131.9, 138.2, 147.8, 150.3, 156.1. MS (EI+) m/z (%): 517.0 (13), 237.1 (100), HRMS (ESI+) Calcd for C14H12Br202HgN4 [ptmp + Br− + Hg2+]+: 516.9952. Found: 516.9962.

After being stirred for 2 h at room temperature, the solvent was evaporated on a rotary evaporator and the residue was redissolved in acetone (3 mL). Yellow crystals of 3 (115 mg, 60% based on ptmp), suitable for X-ray analysis, were collected by filtration and washed with a few drops of acetone. Mp 140-145 °C. Calcd for C28H26AuCl5N8: C, 39.62; H, 3.09; N, 13.20. Found: C, 37.83; H, 2.99; N, 12.58. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3OD) δ 5.90 (s, 2H), 7.25-7.33 (m, 1H), 7.34-7.43 (m, 2H), 7.64 (br d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.71 (br dd, J = 6.3, 6.3 Hz, 1H), 7.75-7.82 (m, 2H), 8.22 (dd, J = 7.8, 7.8 Hz, 1H), 8.41 (s, 1H), 8.70 (br s, 1H). IR (KBr) ν 2531, 1618, 1468, 760, 694 cm-1.

Synthesis of [Hg4Br8(ptmp)2] n  (4)

A mixture of ptmp (12 mg, 0.05 mmol) and HgBr2 (36 mmol, 0.10 mmol) was dissolved in MeOH (1 mL) by gentle heating for a few minutes. The mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature. White crystals of [Hg4Br8(ptmp)2] n  (4, 39 mg, 82%) that formed overnight were collected. Mp 168-172 °C. IR (KBr) ν 1614, 1477, 1466, 1439, 1230, 1194, 1080, 1053, 1005, 815, 757, 723, 687 cm-1. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMF-d 7) δ 5.88 (s, 2H), 7.31-7.43 (m, 3H), 7.43-7.50 (m, 2H), 7.87 (ddd, J = 1.8, 7.7, 7.7 Hz, 1H), 7.92-7.98 (m, 2H), 8.62 (br d, J = 4.2 Hz, 1H), 8.71 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, DMF-d 7) δ 55.5, 122.7, 123.1, 124.0, 126.0, 128.5, 129.5, 131.9, 138.2, 147.8, 150.3, 156.1. MS (EI+) m/z (%): 517.0 (13), 237.1 (100), HRMS (ESI+) Calcd for C14H12Br202HgN4 [ptmp + Br- + Hg2+]+: 516.9952. Found: 516.9962.
